conclusion: The image shows a p-V diagram for an ideal gas process
The gas goes from state A to state B to state C
At state C, the temperature is 300K
State A: approximately p = 3×10⁵ Pa, V = 5×10⁻³ m³
State B: approximately p = 2×10⁵ Pa, V = 6×10⁻³ m³
State C: approximately p = 5×10⁵ Pa, V = 2×10⁻³ m³
For an ideal gas, PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is the number of moles (constant in this process), R is the gas constant, T is temperature
For a fixed amount of gas, we can write: \[\frac{P_1V_1}{T_1} = \frac{P_2V_2}{T_2}\]

premise: Since we know the temperature at state C (T_C = 300K)
conclusion: We can find T_B using \[T_B = \frac{P_B \times V_B}{P_C \times V_C} \times T_C\]

premise: Substitute the values from the graph: \[T_B = \frac{2 \times 10^5 \times 6 \times 10^{-3}}{5 \times 10^5 \times 2 \times 10^{-3}} \times 300\]
